questions.text: Damage control surgery for blunt trauma abdomen includes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Damage control surgery is done to stabilize the unstable patient, since repair of liver laceration can be done only after the patient is stabilized , it is not a component of damage control surgery.

Damage control surgery:

  • Damage control surgery is a staged process which is used when there is an unstable patient whose disturbed physiology hampers definitive management.
  • Initial focus is hemorrhage control, followed by control and limitation of contamination.
  • This can be achieved by simple ligation of vessels, shunting of major arteries and veins, drainage, temporary stapling off of bowel, and therapeutic packing.
  • Then the abdomen is closed temporarily using a plastic sheet with suction.
  • Patient is shifted to the ICU and further resuscitation is carried out.
  • Once the patient is stabilized he is taken back to the OT and definitive repair (eg; suturing of liver laceration) is done.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding congenital anomalies of kidney is false?

choices.text: In renal agenesis both adrenals are usually present in the normal position
Abnormal descent of the metanephros leads to an ectopic kidney
Horseshoe kidneys have an elevated incidence of vesicoureteral reflux
Medullary sponge kidney results from collecting tubular ectasia

questions.solution:
Abnormal ascent not the  descent of the metanephros leads to an ectopic kidney.

  • Because adrenal gland development is unrelated to kidney development, both adrenals are usually present in the normal position.

  • Horseshoe kidneys have an elevated incidence of vesicoureteral reflux and are at increased risk of ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJO).
  • Medullary sponge kidney results from collecting tubular ectasia and is associated with recurrent urolithiasis and an increased incidence of infection in 50% of patients.

questions.text: Which of the following describes degloving injury?

choices.text: Skin is stripped off the subcutaneous tissue
Skin and subcutaneos fat are stripped off the underlying fascia
Skin, subcutaneous fat and fascia stripped off underlying muscle
Muscle also is stripped off leaving exposed bone

questions.solution:
Degloving injury occurs when the skin and subcutaneos fat are stripped by avulsion from its underlying fascia, leaving the neurovascular structures, tendon or bone exposed.

Degloving injury can be either open or closed.

  • Open degloving injury- ex: Ring avulsion injury with the loss of finger skin.
  • Closed degloving injury- ex: Roll over injury caused by motor vehicle.

Investigation for checking viability of skin:

  • Examination under UV light after injection of flourescein.
  • Serial excision until punctate dermal bleeding is obvious.

Image: Degloving injury

questions.text: What is the procedure being shown?
questions.solution:
Percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy or PEG is one of the latest methods of placing a gastrostomy tube.

Steps being done:

  • It uses an endoscope to insufflate the stomach and a direct percutaneos needle puncture made at a point where the stomach abuts the wall.
  • Trochar is inserted and a wire passed into the stomach, which can be caught with a snare.
  • The scope is withdrawn, pulling the wire out through the mouth, at which point it is attached to the gastrostomy tube.
  • The gastrostomy is pulled through into the stomach and out through the track created by the trochar insertion.

questions.text: About splenic artery aneuryms all are correct except:

choices.text: They are twice as common in the female
They are more prone to rupture in pregnancy

questions.solution:
All diagnosed cases of splenic artery aneurysm do not need intervention.

  • In the elderly patient with a calcified aneurysm, there is less risk of rupture and observation may be preferred.
  • In the younger patient with an asymptomatic aneurysm surgery or inteventional radiology is indicated.
  • In patients with pancreatic necrosis, the treatment will include drainage of the septic focus.

questions.text: The uterine artery crosses the ureter ______
questions.solution: The uterine artery crosses the ureter anteriorly (Water under the bridge). Damage to the ureter is more likely at this site (most dangerous site) during hysterectomy.

questions.text: All of the following are true about sliding inguinal hernia except?

choices.text: It occurs at the deep ring medial to the inferior epigastric vessels
Sigmoid colon may be pulled in the the hernia on the left side
Extra caution during repair is needed to prevent injury to the bowel

questions.solution:
Sliding inguinal hernia occurs at the deep ring lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels.

Sliding inguinal hernia:

  • It is an acquired hernia due to weakening of the abdominal wall.
  • This occurs at the deep inguinal ring lateral to the Inferior Epigastric vessels.
  • Retroperitoneal fatty tissue is pushed downwards along the inguinal canal.
  • As more tissue enters the hernia, peritoneum is pulled with it, thus creating a sac.
  • However, the sac has formed secondarily distinguishing it from a classic indirect hernia.

Sigmoid colon can be involved on the left side and the caecum or bladder on the right side.

Surgeons need extra caution during repair as the wall of the large bowel may not be covered by peritoneum and can be damaged.

questions.text: TMPRSS2-ETS fusion genes are associated with _____
questions.solution: TMPRSS2-ETS fusion genes occur in approximately 40–50% of prostate cancers; it is possible that unregulated increased expression of ETS transcription factors interfere with prostatic epithelial cell differentiation.

questions.text: Triple assesment in breast carcinoma includes all of the following except_________
questions.solution:
Calculation of Tumour marker levels is not included in triple assessment.

In any patient who presents with a breast lump, the diagnosis should be made by triple assessment which is a combination of:

  • Clinical assessment
  • Radiological imaging
  • Tissue sample taken for either cytological or histological analysis called as.

The positive predictive value (PPV) of this combination should exceed 99.9%.

questions.text: What is the appropriate age at which corrective surgery should be done for the defect shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows penoscrotal hypospadias. Operations for hypospadias are routinely performed when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age. The infant has good tolerance to surgery by the age of 6 months. The child is well aware of his genitalia and will be toilet trained by the age of 18 months.

Surgery in hypospadias is done to correct problems with the urinary stream and for cosmetic reasons. The main principles of surgery in hypospadias include:

  • Orthoplasty - Chordee correction
  • Urethroplasty - To reposition the urethral opening
  • Glanuloplasty - Reconstruction of glans
  • Skin cover and scrotoplasty

Surgery depends on the site of the hypospadias. Tubularized incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty is the most commonly done procedure. It is done for distal hypospadias.

 Complications of hypospadias surgery include:

  • Urethrocutaneous fistula (most common)
  • Recurrence of chordee
  • Urethral stricture
  • Meatal stenosis
  • Infection

questions.text: What procedure is being done?
questions.solution:
• The procedure that is shown is VATS- Video-Assisted Thoracoscopic Surgery.
  • Many thoracic procedures can be done through VATS like pneumonectomy, lobectomy, empyema drainage, pleural biopsy and pleurodesis.
  • The patient is usually positioned with the disease side uppermost, having had a double lumen endotracheobronchial tube placed by the anaesthetist to allow for single-lung ventilation.
  • Lung biopsy and the treatment of recurrent pneumothorax are the most frequent indications.
  • The principal advantage is that a large incision is avoided resulting in less postoperative pain and a more rapid recovery.

SILS- Single Incision Laparoscopic Surgery

NOTES- Natural Orifice Transluminal Endoscopic Surgery

questions.text: The Bosniak classification system is used in assessing patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The Bosniak classification system is used for assessing patients with renal cysts.

It divides renal cystic masses into five classes based on imaging characteristics seen on CECT. It is helpful in predicting the risks of malignancy and identifying the appropriate choice of clinical follow-up or treatment.

Renal cyst class Risk of malignancy Workup
1 0% Nil
2 0% Nil
2F 5% USG/ CT follow up
3 50%
  • Partial nephrectomy
  • Radiofrequency ablation - in elderly or poor surgical candidates
4 100% Partial or total nephrectomy

questions.text: Which salivary gland tumor appears as a hot spot on technetium-99m scan?
questions.solution:
Warthin tumour is a salivary gland tumour that appears as a hot spot on the technetium-99m scan.

Because of the high mitochondrial content within oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich warthin tumor and oncocytomas incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scan.

Warthins tumour:

  • Warthins tumor is seen in elderly male smokers
  • 2nd most common benign tumour of parotid gland.
  • Usually Unilateral and involves the lower pole of parotid
  • Slow growing well encapsulated, cystic
  • Hot spot on radionuclide scan
  • Histology- Lined by double layer of neoplastic epithelial cells resting on dense lymphoid stroma.
  • Investigation- FNAC
  • Treatment- Superficial parotidectomy

questions.text: What is the most common symptom of peripheral occlusive vascular disease?
questions.solution:
The most common symptom of peripheral obstructive vascular disease is intermittent claudication. 

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

Rest pain is when the disease progresses to a degree that perfusion is severely reduced and cramp-like pain in the calf is felt even at rest. 

A swollen and erythematous limb is seen in critical limb ischemia. When the limb is in the dependent position, there is pooling of blood which causes the limb to appear red and swollen(sunset foot sign).

Buerger's test is done to assess the severity of peripheral vascular disease. In normal individuals, the elevation of the lower limb to a 90-degree angle does not produce any pallor but in affected individuals, even at an elevation of 20-degrees, pallor and venous guttering of the limb can be seen.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady experiences increased frequency of urination and lower abdominal pain which is relieved by micturition. Urinalysis is normal. Cystoscopy reveals fissures and punctate hemorrhages in the bladder mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with normal urinalysis and cystoscopy findings are suggestive of interstitial cystitis.

Interstitial cystitis is a persistent, painful form of chronic cystitis, occurring most frequently in women. It is also known as chronic pelvic pain syndrome or bladder pain syndrome. Its clinical features include:

  • Severe suprapubic pain
  • Urinary frequency
  • Urgency
  • Hematuria
  • Dysuria without evidence of bacterial infection

Cystoscopic findings seen in bladder mucosa are:

  • Fissures
  • Punctate hemorrhages (glomerulations)
  • Ulcerations in the fundus of the bladder (Hunner's ulcer)

The image shows Hunner's ulcer seen in interstitial cystitis:

Treatment options include :

  • Conservative - Patient education about the chronicity of the condition, behavioral modification (timed voiding, bladder training), stress reduction, dietary alteration (avoidance of caffeine and spicy and acidic foods) and physical therapy should be the initial management for all patients.
  • Pharmacological - Neuropathic analgesics (e.g. amitriptyline, pregabalin) are used for those with a significant pain component, whereas antimuscarinics and β3-agonists are used for frequency, nocturia and urgency symptoms.
  • Surgical - For those with Hunner lesions, fulguration or laser to these lesions can be beneficial. Cystodistension as a treatment has variable evidence for success. If these options fail to improve symptoms major surgical reconstruction can be considered in selected cases.

Option b: Malakoplakia is a distinct form of inflammatory reaction seen in chronic cystitis. It appears as soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques.

Option d: Cystitis cystica occurs due to chronic irritation of the bladder mucosa. Cystoscopy reveals cystic lesions in the bladder.

questions.text: Which syndrome is associated with absence of breast?
questions.solution:
• Poland syndrome is associated with congenital absence of one or both the breasts along with absence of sternal portion of the pectoralis major.
  • Pendred syndrome is B/L sensorineural hearing loss associated with goitre.
  • Di George syndrome is associated with absent thymus.
  • Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL) is a hereditary condition associated with tumors arising in multiple organs.

questions.text: Which is the largest artery to the stomach?
questions.solution:
• Left gastric artery is the largest artery to the stomach.
  • It is not uncommon for an aberrant left hepatic artery to originate from it.

Blood supply of the stomach:

  • The celiac trunk gives the left gastric artery, the common hepatic artery and the splenic artery.
  • Right gastric artery is derived from common hepatic artery.
  • Right gastroepiploic artery is a branch of gastroduodenal artery.
  • Left gastroepiploic artery is a branch of splenic artery.

questions.text: Acetohydroxamic acid will be prescribed for patients with which of the following types of renal stones?
questions.solution:
Acetohydroxamic acid is used for the treatment of struvite stone.

It is a urease inhibitor. The urease enzyme generates ammonia from urea, elevating the pH of the urine. This favors the production of struvite stones. Thus, the use of AHA(Acetohydroxamic acid) causes complete, noncompetitive inhibition of urease production, thereby slowing struvite stone growth. Owing to its side-effects, the use of this drug has been restricted in cases of recurrent UTIs, and those intolerant or who refuse surgical management.

It can also be used for oral chemolysis and can potentiate the action of antibiotics.

questions.text: The most common primary cardiac tumor is_______
questions.solution:
Cardiac myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumor.

Myxoma:

  • They usually arise from the interatrial septum near the fossa ovalis in the left atrium.
  • Macroscopically, these tumors are pedunculated with a gelatinous consistency, and the surface may be smooth (65%), villous, or friable
  • 7% of cases are familial as part of Carney complex
  • Carney complex is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by two or more of the following conditions:
    • Atrial and extracardiac myxomas
    • Schwannomas
    • Cutaneous lentiginosis
    • Spotty pigmentation
    • Myxoid fibroadenomas of the breast
    • Endocrine overactivity (pituitary adenomas or primary adrenal hyperplasia with Cushing’s syndrome)
    • Testicular tumors.
  • Cardiac myxomas should be promptly excised after diagnosis due to the significant risk of embolization and cardiovascular complications, including sudden death.

Note:

Most common cardiac tumor is secondaries.

Most common primary tumors in children is rhabdomyomas.

questions.text: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) likely to be?
questions.solution:
In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.4.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A mother brings her 3-month-old infant to the OPD with complaints of him crying while urinating. On palpation, a left-sided flank mass is felt. A USG KUB revealed dilation of the pelvicalyceal system with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. What is the investigation of choice to confirm his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Delayed clearance of contrast or the radiotracer implies obstruction.

Renal isotope scans have replaced intravenous pyelogram as the diagnostic modality of choice in UPJ obstruction.

  • 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects the tubular function.
  • 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function. Hence, it is commonly used to assess GFR.

In obstructive uropathy, 99mTc-DTPA is the preferred isotope as glomerular function declines earlier and more rapidly than tubular function.

Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. 

Tc-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring. 

Note: In children, crying before and after micturition is usually considered normal. While crying during micturition is usually suggestive of pathology.

questions.text: In the ABCDE of melanoma, the D stands for diameter greater than
questions.solution:
In melanoma clinical features, D stands for Diameter which is to be greater than 6mm.

Melanoma most commonly manifests as cutaneous disease, and clinical characteristics include

  • A- Asymmetry
  • B- Border irregularity
  • C- Color variations
  • D- Diameter >6mm
  • E- Evolution or change over time

questions.text: What kind of suturing is depicted below?
questions.solution:
There are four frequently used suture techniques:

Continuous:

Interrupted:

Mattress:

Subcuticular:

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for the condition shown in the picture?
questions.solution:
• The picture shows a sacrococcygeal teratoma.
  • Surgical resection is the standard of care and should be performed promptly because of the risk of hemorrhage and tumor rupture.
  • Operative planning must take into account the degree of intra-abdominal extension.
  • Most tumors can be resected by a posterior approach, in which a chevron incision allows the division of the gluteal muscles, ligation of the blood supply and enbloc resection of the tumor and the coccyx.

questions.text: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is caused by
questions.solution:
Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is caused by Gadolinium contrast used in MRI.

  • Gadolinium containing contrast agents are used in MRI.
  • They can be nephrotoxic in patients with pre-existing renal failure.
  • It causes nephrogenic systemic fibrosis, which is a life-threatening condition whereby connective tissue forms in the skin causing it to become coarse and hard.
  • NSF may also affect other organs, including joints, muscle, liver and heart.
  • High risk gadolinium containing contrast agents are contraindicated in:
    • Severe renal failure
    • Neonates
    • Perioperative period of liver transplantation
    • Not recommended in pregnancy

questions.text: All the following statements about Wilkie's syndrome are true except:

choices.text: It is also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome.
It is most commonly seen in elderly obese women.
Compression occurs at third part of duodenum.
One of the surgical treatment includes duodenojejunostomy.

questions.solution:
Wilkie's syndrome is usually seen in young asthenic women. 

Wilkie's syndrome is also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMA). It is a rare condition that occurs due to the compression of the third part of the duodenum between the superior mesenteric artery and the aorta. 

Normally, the angle between the superior mesenteric artery and aorta (aortomesenteric angle) ranges from 38° to 65°. However, decreasing to an angle of less than 25° causes compression of the third part of the duodenum. 

This syndrome is most commonly seen in young, asthenic women. The main predisposing factors are rapid weight loss, supine immobilization, anorexia nervosa, and placement of body cast. So, it is also called cast syndrome.

Symptoms include profound nausea and vomiting; abdominal distension; weight loss; and postprandial epigastric pain, which varies from intermittent to constant, depending on the severity of the duodenal obstruction.

A barium study of the upper gastrointestinal tract demonstrates cessation of the flow of barium from the duodenum to the jejunum. A CT scan can be used to confirm SMA by measuring the aortomesenteric angle. The surgical treatment includes duodenojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy, and duodenal derotation.

questions.text: Proper handling of a traumatically amputated digit or limb includes which of the following?

choices.text: Place dry in a waterproof bag

questions.solution:
• Amputated part of limb should be wrapped in a moistened gauze.
  • In preperation for replantation, the amputated part and proximal stump should be appropriately treated.
  • Amputated part:
    • Should be wrapped in moistened gauze and placed in a sealed bag.
    • This bag should then be placed in an ice water bath (no dry ice).
    • Do not allow the part to contact ice directly; frostbite can occur in the amputated part,which will decrease its chance of survival after replantation.
  • Proximal stump:
    • Bleeding should be controlled in the proximal stump by as minimal a means necessary
    • The stump should be dressed with a nonadherent gauze and bulky dressing.

questions.text: Which of the following are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysms?

choices.text: Size more than 5.5 cm in males
Size more than 5 cm in females

questions.solution:
All the given are indications for surgical intervention in abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The indications include:

  • Size >5.5 cm in males (option A)
  • Size >4.5-5 cm in females (option B)
  • Expansion of >0.5 cm within 6 months or >1 cm in one year (option C)
  • Painful, tender aneurysm 
  • Thrombosed aneurysm, aneurysm with distal emboli 

The rupture risk is high for aneurysms >5.5 cm and begins to rise exponentially with an increase in size. Women are at higher risk for rupture than men, with a lower threshold of 4.5 to 5.0 cm (depending on the reference used).

Screening is done for:

  • Cardiovascular patients in men and women (60-85 years)
  • Men and women >50 years with positive family history 
  • Annual screening in asymptomatic patients with 4-4.5 cm size, size >4.5 cm once in every 6 months.

Management of AAA can be done by open repair or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). About 75% of infrarenal aneurysms are suitable for endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR), depending on the morphology of the aneurysm assessed by a CT scan.

Aneurysms that fall below the mentioned indications may safely be followed with CT or ultrasound at 6-month intervals since long-term outcomes to routine follow-up are equivalent to earlier surgical repair of the aneurysm. Smoking cessation is very important and reduces the mortality rate.

The technique of EVAR:

questions.text: The image below depicts the abnormalities resulting from the persistence of the omphalomesenteric duct. Identify the structure marked as B in the given image.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as B in the given image is Meckel's diverticulum.

Omphalomesentric duct abnormalities:

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between the yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which gets obliterated eventually.
  • The persistence of the vitello-intestinal duct can lead to various abnormalities depending on the part of the duct that is persistent.
    • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula.
    • Persistence of the distal end near the umbilicus leads to an umbilical polyp or sinus.
    • Persistence of distal end with mucus retention leads to a cyst which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by means of a fibrous band.
    • A fully patent vitello-intestinal duct can lead to an enterocutaneous fistula.

Meckel’s diverticula:

  • The persistence of the intestinal end of the omphalomesenteric duct (vitellointestinal duct) is called as Meckel’s diverticulum.
  • It is a congenital, true diverticulum (contains all the layers of the bowel).
  • It mostly arises from the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum.
  • Rule of 2s:
    • Seen in 2% of the population
    • Within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
    • 2 inches in length
    • Has 2 types of ectopic mucosa (gastric and pancreatic).

Complications:

  • Bleeding
  • Intestinal obstruction
  • Diverticulitis

Investigation:

  • Children- Scintigraphy with sodium 99m Tc-pertechnetate
  • Adults- Barium studies

Treatment: Diverticulectomy or resection of the segment of the ileum.

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is appropriate for congenital hydrocele in a 2-year-old child?
questions.solution:
• Congenital hydroceles are treated by herniotomy if they do not resolve spontaneously.
  • In congenital hydrocele, the processus vaginalis is patent and connects with the peritoneal cavity. Hence all that is required for treatment is ligation of the processus (herniotomy).
  • Remember that herniotomy is the treatment of choice for congenital hydrocele and hernia.

questions.text: Identify the type of flap:
questions.solution:
• This is a type of pedicled or islanded flap.
  • Flaps are tissues that are transferred with a blood supply.
  • Pedicled/islanded flaps: The axial blood supply allows the flap to be swung round on a stalk or even fully islanded so that the business end of the skin being transferred can have the pedicle buried.

Other types of flaps include:

  • Random flaps: Three sides of a rectangle are used, length to breadth ratio not more than 1.5:1.
  • Axial flap: Much longer flaps can be used, based on known blood vessels.
  • Free flaps: Blood supply has been isolated, disconnected and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site.
  • Composite flap: Various tissues are transferred together, often skin with bone or muscle (osseocutaneous or myocutaneous).
  • Perforator flaps: This description refers to a whole new subgroup of axial flaps in which tissues are isolated on small perforating vessels that run from more major blood vessels to supply the surface.

questions.text: A man is diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma. What is the tumour marker used in the detection and management of his condition?
questions.solution:
Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is used in the detection and management of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

It is an oncofetal glycoprotein. Levels are elevated in the fetus, fall to lower levels after birth, and are elevated during pregnancy. It is synthesised by hepatocytes and endodermal-derived gastrointestinal tissues. The upper limit of normal for a healthy, nonpregnant adult is < 25 ng/ mL. 

Use of AFP in HCC:

  • Detection- Levels > 400 ng/mL with typical radiological findings are suggestive of HCC. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is not elevated in fibrolamellar HCC.
  • Screening- the combination of AFP and ultrasound improves the efficacy of screening for HCC.
  • Prognosis- degree of AFP elevation corresponds to tumor size. A high rate of increase of AFP (AFP doubling time) is associated with a poor prognosis.
  • Monitoring- after complete resection, AFP levels should drop and remain less than 10 ng/ml. A postoperative rise in AFP is the best indicator of recurrent disease.

Alpha-fetoprotein is also produced by a variety of conditions, such as:

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Hepatoblastoma
  • Non-seminomatous germ cell tumours of the ovary and testis (e.g., yolk sac and embryonal carcinoma)
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Pregnancy and benign liver disease (e.g., viral hepatitis, cirrhosis)
  • Gastrointestinal tract tumours
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia (along with CEA)

Limitations of AFP include low sensitivity and specificity. It is not specific to HCC and can occur with intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma and colorectal metastases.

Related Pearl: Differentiating features between hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and fibrolamellar carcinoma

Parameter

HCC

Fibrolamellar carcinoma

Male-to-female ratio

2:1  to 8:1

No gender predilection

Median age

55 years

25 years

Tumor 

Invasive

 Well circumscribed

Resectability

<25%

50%–75%

Cirrhosis

90%

5%

AFP positive

80%

5%

Hepatitis B positive

65%

5%

AFP: alpha-fetoprotein

questions.text: In Paget-Schroetter syndrome which of the following structure is affected?
questions.solution:
In Paget-Schroetter syndrome, the subclavian vein is affected.

Compression of subclavian vein between anterior scalene, clavicle, and the first rib can produce axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis. It results in severe upper extremity pain and swelling,  that is exaggerated by exercise.

Activities such as throwing, swimming, and weightlifting can cause microtrauma of the venous intima that initiates thrombus formation.

questions.text: NOTES stands for________
questions.solution:
NOTES refer to Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery

  • NOTES is a technique where surgeons enter the peritoneal cavity via endoscopic puncture of a hollow viscus.
  • Transvaginal NOTES cholecystectomies have been performed in humans successfully.
  • The closure of the visceral puncture site is the issue that really has prevented widespread uptake of this technique,as transgastric and transcolonic closure of peritoneal entry sites
  • NOTES was first done by Indians (Dr. G .V Rao and Dr. N Reddy). They did a transgastric appendicectomy.

questions.text: According to the modified Johnson anatomic classification for gastric ulcer an NSAID induced ulcer would be what type?
questions.solution:
NSAID induced ulcer refers to Type V of Modified Johnson anatomical classification of gastric ulcer.

Modified Johnson anatomical classification of gastric ulcer:

Type Location Acid level
I Lesser curve at incisura Low to normal
II Gastric body with duodenal ulcer Increased
III Prepyloric Increased
IV High on lesser curve Normal
V Anywhere Normal , NSAID induced

Modified Johnson Anatomical Classification of Gastric Ulcer:

  • Type 1- Most common
  • Type 2 and 3- Increased acid levels
  • Type 5- NSAID induced ulcer
  • Type 5- occur anywhere in the stomach

Related Pearl: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine.

  Type Of Ulcer               Location Acid Production Surgical Management
          Type I            Gastric body             Low Distal Gastrectomy Billroth Type 1
          Type II                 Antrum    Low to Normal Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI
          Type III Within 3cm of the pylorus; Accompanied by duodenal ulcers    Normal or High  Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI  
          Type IV                  Cardia              Low  Pouchet, Csendes Procedure

 

The other classification is Modified Johnson's Classification which is as follows: 

Modified Johnson classification for gastric ulcer

I. Lesser curve, incisura - Normal Acid secretion

II. Body of stomach, incisura + duodenal ulcer (active or healed) - Increased Acid secretion

III. Prepyloric - Increased Acid secretion

IV. High on lesser curve - Normal acid secretion

V. Medication induced (NSAID/ acetylsalicylic acid), anywhere in stomach

questions.text: What is the maximum safe cold storage time for kidney?
questions.solution:
The maximum safe cold storage time for kidney transplant is about 36 hours.

The optimal and maximum cold storage times for different organs (appproximate):

Organ

Optimum

(hours)

Safe maximum

(hours)
Kidney <18 36
Liver <12 18
Pancreas <10 18
Small intestine <4 6
Heart <3 6
Lung <3 8

questions.text: On per rectal examination, which of the following findings will help you identify a malignant prostate lesion?

choices.text: Rectal mucosa mobile over the prostate

questions.solution:
Palpable nodules over the prostate is highly suggestive of carcinoma.

Features of carcinoma of the prostate Features of benign disease of the prostate
  • Hard consistency
  • Rectal mucosa immobile over the prostate
  • Obliteration of the median groove
  • Nodular surface
  • Firm consistency
  • Rectal mucosa mobile over the prostate
  • Residual urine may be felt as a fluctuating swelling above the prostate
  • Smooth surface

questions.text: Abdominal wall mass that does not cross the midline and remains palpable when rectus is contracted is called_________
questions.solution: Forthergill sign is seen in rectus muscle hematoma. It refers to an abdominal wall mass that does not cross the midline and remains palpable when rectus is contracted.

questions.text: A BIRADS category score of 0 would mean?
questions.solution:
BIRADS score of 0 refers to Incomplete assessment.

BIRADS stands for Breast Imaging Reporting And Data System.

BIRADS final assessment category:

Category Definition
0 Incomplete assessment – need additional imaging evaluation or prior mammogram for comparison
1 Negative- nothing to comment on; usually recommend annual screening
2 Benign finding- usually recommend annual screening
3 Probably benign finding (<2%mallignant)- initial short – interval follow up suggested
4 Suspicious abnormality (2%-95% malignant)- biopsy should be considered
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy (>95%malignant)- appropriate action should be taken
6 Known biopsy-proven malignancy

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the triad of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Hematuria is not included in the triad of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms.

A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm is a surgical emergency. The rupture can be anterior or posterior. In the anterior rupture, there may be bleeding into the peritoneal cavity whereas, in the posterior rupture, a retroperitoneal hematoma may be present. 

The features include severe abdominal or back pain, hypotension, and pulsatile abdominal mass.

Management is as follows

  • Oxygen, IV replacement, and central line
  • Maintenance of systolic blood pressure but not beyond 100.
  • Catheterization
  • Cross-matching blood
  • Shifting the patient rapidly to the operating room.

questions.text: All of the following form the classic triad of symptoms in achalasia cardia except:
questions.solution:
Dyspepsia is not included in the triad of classical symptoms of achalasia cardia.

The classic triad of presenting symptoms of achalasia cardia consists of:

  1. Dysphagia
  2. Regurgitation
  3. Weight loss

Manometry is the gold standard for the diagnosis of achalasia.

There is a lack of peristaltic waves in the body and a failure of relaxation of the LES.

Surgical management is usually with laparoscopic modified Heller’s myotomy.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: Facial flushing and dilatation of cervical veins upon raising the arms above the head- this sign is known as?
questions.solution:
• Positive Pemberton’s sign—facial flushing and dilatation of cervical veins upon raising the arms above the head.
  • Retrosternal extension of a large goiter may result in impeded flow in the superior vena cava, leading to dilated veins over the chest wall.
  • This may become more prominent when patients raise their arms above the head—Pemberton’s sign.

Option A:

Pizzillo’s method is used in obese and short necked patients to examine goiter.

Option B:

Pemberton sign is used to detect retrosternal goiter.

Option C:

Berry sign is absence of carotid pulsations seen in carcinoma thyroid.

Option D:

Crile’s method is used to examine a small thyroid nodule using thumb.

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements about carotid body tumor except

choices.text: It is seen in people who live at high altitude
10% patients have a positive family history
Carotid angiogram shows splaying of the carotid bifurcation

questions.solution:
Carotid body tumors/ chemodectoma are not hormonally active and the tumors are usually benign.

Carotid body tumour:

  • It occurs in people who live at high altitude
  • Occur in the 5th decade,10% have family history
  • Slowly growing tumour.
  • Carotid angiogram shows Lyre sign (splaying of the carotid bifurcation)
  • MRI angiography shows splaying of internal and external carotid arteries (Lyre’s sign).

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient presented to the hospital after a road traffic accident with a fracture of the pelvis. There was urinary retention and blood at the urethral meatus. On digital rectal examination, he had a high-riding prostate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with blood at the tip of the meatus and high-riding prostate on examination is suggestive of rupture of the membranous urethra.

Rupture Membranous urethra Bulbar urethra
Cause Fracture of the pelvis Blow to the perineum (fall-astride injury-straddle injury)
Clinical features
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at urethral meatus
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (Vermooten sign)
  • Urinary retention
  • Blood at urethral meatus
  • Perineal bruising and hematoma
Investigation Retrograde urethrogram  Retrograde urethrogram

In both cases, the initial management should be the insertion of a suprapubic catheter. Passing a catheter blindly per urethra is not advised as this can convert a partial tear into a complete tear. 

However, delayed urethroplasty is the definitive management for complete urethral tear.

questions.text: Whipple’s triad is seen in _______
questions.solution:
Whipple’s triad is seen in insulinoma.

It includes:

  • Symptoms of hypoglycemia after fasting or exercise.
  • Plasma glucose levels <50 mg/ dl (<2.8 mmol/L).
  • Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose.

Whipple’s operation: Pancreatico-duodenectomy; done in carcinoma head of the pancreas.

questions.text: Which day is morula 16 stage?
Identify the type of brain herniation marked as 1.
questions.solution:
The type of brain herniation marked as 1 in the above image is subfalcine herniation.

In the image:

  • Subfalcine herniation marked by 1: herniation of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri
  • Herniation with midline shift ,marked by 2
  • Uncal herniation marked by 3 (uncus is part of temporal lobe)-can compress the ipsilateral third nerve
  • Central herniation marked by 4 is associated with compression of brainstem structures.
  • Tonsillar herniation marked by 5 (part of the cerebellum) is associated with compression of brainstem structures.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about phyllodes tumor?

choices.text: It most commonly occurs in women less than 40 yrs
They present as large, sometimes massive with bosselated surface
They remain mobile on the chest wall

questions.solution:
• Phyllodes tumor usually occur in women over the age of 40 years, but can appear in younger women.
  • Phyllodes tumor is mostly benign even though it is also called as cystosarcoma phyllodes or as serocystic disease of Brodie.
  • They are usually mobile over the chest wall Despite their large size.
  • Histologically, there is a wide variation with some of low malignant potential and others having a higher mitotic index.
  • Treatment:
    • Benign type- Enucleation or wide local excision
    • Massive tumours, recurrent tumours and malignant type- Mastectomy

questions.text: Which is the most common functioning tumor in patients with adrenal incidentalomas?
questions.solution:
Incidentaloma is an adrenal mass,detected incidentally by imaging studies conducted for other reasons.

The most common incidentaloma is a non-functioning adenoma.

The most common functioning tumor is a Cushing’s adenoma.

Prevalence of tumours in patients with Incidentaloma:

Tumour Prevalence (%)
Non-functioning adenoma  78
Cushing’s adenoma 7
Adrenocortical carcinoma  4
Pheochromocytoma 4
Myelolipoma  2
Cyst 2
Metastases 2
Conn’s adenoma 1

questions.text: Large doses of iodide given to patient with hyperplastic goitre causing hyperthyroidism is called as_______
questions.solution:
Jod–Basedow thyrotoxicosis:

Large doses of iodide given to a patient with a hyperplastic endemic goitre that is iodine avid may produce temporary hyperthyroidism and very occasionally persistent hyperthyroidism.

Other options

Option A- Wolff chaikoff effect:

  • Hypothyroidism caused by ingestion of large amount of iodine (thyroid constipation).

Option C- Secondary thyrotoxicosis:

  • The goitre is nodular. The onset is insidious and may present with cardiac failure or atrial ﬁbrillation. The hyperthyroidism is not severe and very infrequently is associated with eye signs.

Option D- Thyrotoxicosis facticia:

  • Hyperthyroidism may be induced by taking thyroxine, but only if the dosage exceeds the normal requirements of 0.15–0.25 mg per day.
